headline: b'Facebook Admits It Was Used to Incite Violence in Myanmar'
lead_paragraph: Facebook has long promoted itself as a tool for bringing people together to make the world a better place. Now the social media giant has acknowledged that in Myanmar it did the opposite, and human rights groups say it has a lot of work to do to fix that.

headline: b'\xe2\x80\x98Facebook Cannot Be Trusted to Regulate Itself\xe2\x80\x99'
lead_paragraph: “Facebook cannot be trusted to regulate itself,” tweeted Rhode Island Representative David Cicilline on Wednesday night.

headline: b'How Plato Foresaw Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Folly'
lead_paragraph: In ancient Egypt there lived a wise king named Thamus. One day he was visited by a clever god called Theuth.

headline: b'Democrats Should Un-Friend Facebook'
lead_paragraph: In their recent book “LikeWar: The Weaponization of Social Media,” P.W. Singer and Emerson T. Brooking describe the surprising role of online communication in spurring gang violence in Chicago. They quote Chicago Alderman Joe Moore saying that, contrary to popular belief, most gang disputes begin not with conflict over drug sales or territory, but with insults hurled on the internet. (Slang terms for online threats, the authors report, include “Facebook drilling” and “wallbanging.”) According to Singer and Brooking, “80 percent of the fights that break out in Chicago schools are now instigated online.”

headline: b'How Facebook Has Handled Recent Scandals'
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: b'Facebook Failed to Police How Its Partners Handled User Data'
lead_paragraph: Facebook failed to closely monitor device makers after granting them access to the personal data of hundreds of millions of people, according to a previously unreported disclosure to Congress last month.

headline: b'Facebook and the Fires'
lead_paragraph: When I flew into San Francisco last Sunday, the haze shrouding the city was not the usual charming fog, and there was an acrid smell, like a barbecue on steroids. California was on fire.

headline: b'How to Make Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99 Work'
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, has announced a plan to create an independent body to make decisions about what kinds of content his site’s users will be allowed to post. It’s a development that he hinted at when he said on a podcast in April, “You can imagine some sort of structure, almost like a Supreme Court, that is made up of independent folks who don’t work for Facebook, who ultimately make the final judgment call on what should be acceptable speech in a community that reflects the social norms and values of people all around the world.”

headline: b'On Thanksgiving Eve, Facebook Acknowledges Details of Times Investigation'
lead_paragraph: Joining a long tradition of companies and campaigns that drop bad news on holidays, Facebook on Thanksgiving eve took responsibility for hiring a Washington-based lobbying company, Definers Public Affairs, that pushed negative stories about Facebook’s critics, including the philanthropist George Soros.

headline: b'The Week in Tech: Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Three Big Problems'
lead_paragraph: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline: b'Facebook Used People\xe2\x80\x99s Data to Favor Certain Partners and Punish Rivals, Documents Show'
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Facebook used the mountains of data it collected on users to favor certain partners and punish rivals, giving companies such as Airbnb and Netflix special access to its platform while cutting off others that it perceived as threats.

headline: b'Congress May Have Fallen for Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Trap, but You Don\xe2\x80\x99t Have To'
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, Facebook confronted yet another privacy scandal, in light of leaked court documents suggesting that its staff discussed the idea of selling user data as long ago as 2012. Facebook's director of developer platforms and programs, Konstantinos Papamiltiadis, responded, “To be clear, Facebook has never sold anyone’s data.” It was the same denial that Mark Zuckerberg issued before the Senate in April 2018: “We do not sell data to advertisers. We don’t sell data to anyone.”

headline: b'How to Delete Facebook'
lead_paragraph: You may have decided enough is enough: It’s time to delete Facebook.

headline: b'Facebook Sued by District of Columbia Over Cambridge Analytica'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The attorney general of the District of Columbia, Karl Racine, sued Facebook on Wednesday for allowing the political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica to harvest the private data of tens of millions of the social network’s users.

headline: b'Facebook Rebuked for Failing to Disclose Data-Sharing Deals'
lead_paragraph: Facebook and some of the other largest technology firms in the world faced sharp criticism on Wednesday for failing to disclose the extent of the social network’s data-sharing deals, many of which went back to the company’s early years.

headline: b'5 Ways Facebook Shared Your Data'
lead_paragraph: Facebook for years gave major tech companies, including Yahoo and Netflix, greater access to people’s data than it disclosed, a New York Times investigation found. The partnerships helped Facebook draw new users, ramp up its advertising revenue and embed itself on sites across the web.

headline: b'Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Data Sharing and Privacy Rules: 5 Takeaways From Our Investigation'
lead_paragraph: You are the product: That is the deal many Silicon Valley companies offer to consumers. The users get free search engines, social media accounts and smartphone apps, and the companies use the personal data they collect — your searches, “likes,” phone numbers and friends — to target and sell advertising.

headline: b'Inside Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Secret Rulebook for Global Political Speech'
lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — In a glass conference room at its California headquarters, Facebook is taking on the bonfires of hate and misinformation it has helped fuel across the world, one post at a time.

headline: b'5 Takeaways From Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Leaked Moderation Documents'
lead_paragraph: Sometimes an emoji is just an emoji. Sometimes it may be a threat.

headline: b'In Screening for Suicide Risk, Facebook Takes On Tricky Public Health Role'
lead_paragraph: A police officer on the late shift in an Ohio town recently received an unusual call from Facebook.

headline: b'We Should Be Able to Take Facebook to Court'
lead_paragraph: After The New York Times revealed last month that Facebook continued to share personal information of millions of consumers with companies like Netflix, Yahoo, Spotify and Google — despite contrary assertions to Congress — many people decided to delete their Facebook accounts. But if Facebook’s actions, as described by The Times, violated the law, consumers should be able to send an even more powerful message, one that could leave a much larger imprint on the company’s ledger books: suing the company for damages.

headline: b'Deleting Facebook Won\xe2\x80\x99t Fix the Problem'
lead_paragraph: When news broke that Facebook users’ private messages were not necessarily private, Taunya Richards, 44, a real estate appraiser in Hillsboro, Ore., immediately panicked: Had she endangered her son? She thought back to her chats with her mother in Idaho, who prefers Facebook’s messenger to texting. Her son is a specialist in the Army; using the Facebook-owned encrypted messaging platform WhatsApp, he had kept her updated as he traveled to what she described as a dangerous foreign base whose location she was supposed to keep secret. She had then sent those location updates to her mother using Facebook Messenger. Now she wonders who has that data.

headline: b'Facebook Identifies Russia-Linked Misinformation Campaign'
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Facebook identified two disinformation campaigns originating from Russia — including one tied to an agency controlled by the Kremlin — that were targeted at users in Europe and Central Asia. The company said on Thursday it had deleted nearly 500 pages and accounts that had posted the misleading messages.

headline: b'How Secrecy Fuels Facebook Paranoia'
lead_paragraph: In December of last year, the Senate Intelligence Committee released two reports it had commissioned concerning Russia’s efforts to influence the 2016 election. The outline of the interference effort has always been easy to make out, but key questions about its significance — Could Russia really affect voter sentiment by posting? Did trolls really lower voter turnout in key states? — are still, in large part, matters for speculation. And the committee’s findings did little to change that.

headline: b'F.T.C. Is Said to Be Considering Large Facebook Fines'
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission is in the advanced stages of its investigation into whether Facebook violated privacy rules and is expected to seek large fines from the company, according to two people familiar with the inquiry.

headline: b'This Is Your Brain Off Facebook'
lead_paragraph: The world’s most common digital habit is not easy to break, even in a fit of moral outrage over the privacy risks and political divisions Facebook has created, or amid concerns about how the habit might affect emotional health.

headline: b'An Anti-Facebook Manifesto, by an Early Facebook Investor'
lead_paragraph: ZUCKED Waking Up to the Facebook CatastropheBy Roger McNamee

headline: b'Assessing the Facebook Problem'
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: b'Maybe Only Tim Cook Can Fix Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Privacy Problem'
lead_paragraph: It’s nowhere in his job description, but Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, has recently taken a moonlight gig as Facebook’s privacy watchdog.

headline: b'Does Facebook Really Know How Many Fake Accounts It Has?'
lead_paragraph: Facebook sells advertisers on its access to real people — 2.32 billion of them, a network that exceeds the populations of North America, South America and Africa combined.

headline: b'Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Profits and Revenue Climb as It Gains More Users'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook’s worst year ever was its best year ever when it came to its business.

headline: b'Germany Restricts Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Data Gathering'
lead_paragraph: In a direct challenge to Facebook’s business model, Germany’s competition authority on Thursday sharply curtailed how the tech giant may profile people, saying that users could refuse to allow the company to combine their Facebook information with data about their activities on other sites.

headline: b'How to Stop Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Dangerous App Integration Ploy'
lead_paragraph: In response to calls that Facebook be forced to divest itself of WhatsApp and Instagram, Mark Zuckerberg has instead made a strategic power grab: He intends to put Instagram, WhatsApp and Facebook Messenger onto a unified technical infrastructure. The integrated apps are to be encrypted to protect users from hackers. But who’s going to protect users from Facebook?

headline: b'Consumer Groups Accuse Facebook of Duping Children'
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than a dozen children’s advocacy groups on Thursday accused Facebook of knowingly deceiving children into racking up fees from games on its social network, the latest in a string of complaints against the company sent to federal regulators.

headline: b'Facebook Targeted in Scathing Report by British Parliament'
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After 18 months investigating Facebook and online misinformation, a British parliamentary committee issued a scathing report on Monday, accusing the company of breaking data privacy and competition laws and calling for new regulations to rein in the technology industry.

headline: b'Facebook and Telegram Are Hoping to Succeed Where Bitcoin Failed'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Some of the world’s biggest internet messaging companies are hoping to succeed where cryptocurrency start-ups have failed by introducing mainstream consumers to the alternative world of digital coins.

headline: b'Facebook Just Shoplifted Snapchat\xe2\x80\x99s Best Idea'
lead_paragraph: If you want to know why Mark Zuckerberg is suddenly so interested in privacy, I have one word for you: data.

headline: b'Mark Zuckerberg Wants Facebook to Emulate WeChat. Can It?'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As Mark Zuckerberg begins shifting Facebook to private messaging and away from public sharing and open conversations, the vision he has sketched out for the future of social networking already exists — just not in the United States.

headline: b'Facebook Announces Plan to Curb Vaccine Misinformation'
lead_paragraph: Facebook announced Thursday its first policy to combat misinformation about vaccines, following in the footsteps of Pinterest and YouTube.

headline: b'The Man Deciding Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Fate'
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission has no shortage of critics who say it cannot protect Americans from the prying eyes of Big Tech. Instead of forceful action against the likes of Facebook and Google, they say, the F.T.C. leans on rules that make it hard to impose penalties bigger than rounding errors for the companies.

headline: b'Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Biblically Bad Week'
lead_paragraph: Exactly when did Facebook become the Job of internet companies?

headline: b'Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Data Deals Are Under Criminal Investigation'
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are conducting a criminal investigation into data deals Facebook struck with some of the world’s largest technology companies, intensifying scrutiny of the social media giant’s business practices as it seeks to rebound from a year of scandal and setbacks.

headline: b'The Case for Investigating Facebook'
lead_paragraph: A year ago, the world learned that Facebook allowed a political consulting company called Cambridge Analytica to exploit the personal information of up to 87 million users, to obtain data that would help the company’s clients “fight a culture war” in America.

headline: b'Facebook Did Not Securely Store Passwords. Here\xe2\x80\x99s What You Need to Know.'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook said on Thursday that millions of user account passwords had been stored insecurely, potentially allowing employees to gain access to people’s accounts without their knowledge.

headline: b'Facebook Halts Ad Targeting Cited in Bias Complaints'
lead_paragraph: After years of criticism, Facebook announced on Tuesday that it would stop allowing advertisers in key categories to show their messages only to people of a certain race, gender or age group.

headline: b'I Deleted Facebook Last Year. Here\xe2\x80\x99s What Changed (and What Didn\xe2\x80\x99t).'
lead_paragraph: When Facebook and its family of apps experienced a daylong malfunction last week, millions of people got a taste of what life would be like if the social network were out of their lives for good.

headline: b'Facebook Faces a Reckoning for Redlining'
lead_paragraph: The automated decision systems that are pervasive in banking, the criminal justice system and the tech sector can easily amplify forms of discrimination that were once attributable to human bias only. The Department of Housing and Urban Development spoke to this problem on Thursday when it charged Facebook with violating the Fair Housing Act of 1968 by permitting advertisers to restrict access to housing ads based on user characteristics like race, religion or national origin.

headline: b'The Mounting Federal Investigations Into Facebook'
lead_paragraph: Facebook now faces investigations into its business practices from a variety of federal agencies. Officials have opened inquiries into possible civil and criminal violations of laws related to privacy, corporate governance and discrimination.

headline: b'Mark Zuckerberg\xe2\x80\x99s Call to Regulate Facebook, Explained'
lead_paragraph: Facebook has faced months of scrutiny for a litany of ills, from spreading misinformation to not properly protecting its users’ data to allowing foreign meddling in elections.

headline: b'Facebook Wants a Faux Regulator for Internet Speech. It Won\xe2\x80\x99t Happen.'
lead_paragraph: In an opinion article published last weekend, Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, said he agreed with the growing consensus that Facebook — and other social media companies — should be subject to more regulation. The article, published in four countries and three languages, was fated to be misunderstood from the start.

headline: b'Regulators Around the World Are Circling Facebook'
lead_paragraph: Regulators on four continents are preparing for a long-awaited showdown with Facebook, after years of disinterest and half-steps.

headline: b'Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Unintended Consequence'
lead_paragraph: Over the past several years we’ve learned a lot about the unintended consequences of social media. Platforms intended to bring us closer together make us angrier and more isolated. Platforms aimed at democratizing speech empower demagogues. Platforms celebrating community violate our privacy in ways we scarcely realize and serve as conduits for deceptions hiding in plain sight.

headline: b'Facebook, \xe2\x80\x98Asleep at the Wheel\xe2\x80\x99'
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: b'Facebook Unveils Redesign as It Tries to Move Past Privacy Scandals'
lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Mark Zuckerberg declared in March that he planned to shift Facebook away from being a public town square and to private communications. Now, the chief executive is rolling out the first in a series of changes to achieve that.

headline: b'It\xe2\x80\x99s Time to Break Up Facebook'
lead_paragraph: The last time I saw Mark Zuckerberg was in the summer of 2017, several months before the Cambridge Analytica scandal broke. We met at Facebook’s Menlo Park, Calif., office and drove to his house, in a quiet, leafy neighborhood. We spent an hour or two together while his toddler daughter cruised around. We talked politics mostly, a little about Facebook, a bit about our families. When the shadows grew long, I had to head out. I hugged his wife, Priscilla, and said goodbye to Mark.

headline: b'Facebook Restricts Live Streaming After New Zealand Shooting'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When 51 people were killed in Christchurch, New Zealand, in March, the suspect, an Australian man, broadcast the attack live on Facebook. The video spread across the internet.

headline: b'Can Facebook Be Fixed? Should It Be?'
lead_paragraph: “Mark’s influence is staggering, far beyond that of anyone else in the private sector or in government,” wrote Chris Hughes, a Facebook founder, of his fellow founder Mark Zuckerberg in an Op-Ed questioning the benefit to society of his former company’s size and power: “It is time to break up Facebook.”

headline: b'Why Trump Likes Facebook'
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: b'Facebook Says It Is More Aggressively Enforcing Content Rules'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook, facing withering criticism from governments around the world, said Thursday that it had been more aggressive in recent months about scrubbing its platform of hate speech.

headline: b'Nancy Pelosi Criticizes Facebook for Handling of Altered Videos'
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday strongly rebuked Facebook, saying the company’s refusal to take down altered videos of her demonstrated how the social network contributed to misinformation and enabled Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.

headline: b'A Fake Zuckerberg Video Challenges Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Rules'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Two weeks ago, Facebook declined to remove a doctored video in which the speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi, seemed to drunkenly slur her speech. Over the weekend, two British artists released a doctored video of Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, as a sly comment on the spread of false information online.

headline: b'When Rohingya Refugees Fled to India, Hate on Facebook Followed'
lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, India — Mohammad Salim, a Rohingya Muslim refugee, thought he had left genocidal violence and Facebook vitriol behind when he fled his native country, Myanmar, in 2013.

headline: b'Facebook Plans Global Financial System Based on Cryptocurrency'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook unveiled an ambitious plan on Tuesday to create an alternative financial system that relies on a cryptocurrency that the company has been secretly working on for more than a year.

headline: b'Launching a Global Currency Is a Bold, Bad Move for Facebook'
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Facebook, in partnership with a surfeit of other large and powerful corporations, including Uber, Spotify, PayPal and VISA, announced that it would lead the effort to create a new global currency called Libra. “We believe,” says the organization that will govern the currency, “that the world needs a global, digitally native currency that brings together the attributes of the world’s best currencies: stability, low inflation, wide global acceptance and fungibility.”

headline: b'The Real Reason for Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s New Cryptocurrency'
lead_paragraph: Facebook says its new cryptocurrency, Libra, is a tool for financial inclusion and disrupting the world’s cumbersome payment systems. In reality, there is a deeper motivation behind it, although not the one its critics imagine: Libra is the last, best hope to re-establish trust between Facebook and the world.

headline: b'F.T.C. Approves Facebook Fine of About $5 Billion'
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission has approved a fine of roughly $5 billion against Facebook for mishandling users’ personal information, according to three people briefed on the vote, in what would be a landmark settlement that signals a newly aggressive stance by regulators toward the country’s most powerful technology companies.

headline: b'Fed Chair Raises \xe2\x80\x98Serious Concerns\xe2\x80\x99 About Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Cryptocurrency Project'
lead_paragraph: Facebook is facing a growing chorus of doubts about its new Libra cryptocurrency project from authorities around the world, ahead of two congressional hearings on the initiative next week.

headline: b'Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Digital Money Could Mean Fabulous Wealth. Or Not.'
lead_paragraph: Jack Ma, a co-founder of Alibaba,  was recently asked about the secret of his success. “I know nothing about technology,” he said. “I know nothing about marketing.” He said what he knows about is people. A successful business, he said, is all about making people happy.

headline: b'Facebook Cryptocurrency Plans Have a Problem: Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Reputation'
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers made it clear at a Senate Banking Committee hearing on Tuesday that they believe the biggest roadblock to Facebook’s plan to enter the world of cryptocurrency and global finance is the company’s reputation.

headline: b'Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Cryptocurrency Faces Second Day of Critical Hearings'
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers said in a House hearing on Wednesday that Facebook’s plan to enter the world of cryptocurrency and global finance could threaten sovereign currencies or even destabilize governments.

headline: b'A $5 Billion Fine for Facebook Won\xe2\x80\x99t Fix Privacy'
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission issued a $5 billion fine against Facebook on Wednesday. It’s an eye-popping number for sure, one that blows previous fines out of the water.

headline: b'Another Victim in Facebook Romance Scams: A U.S. Congressman'
lead_paragraph: In 2015, Representative Adam Kinzinger had an unusual visitor at his constituent office inside a bus station in Rockford, Ill. A woman from India had flown to meet Mr. Kinzinger, claiming that she had developed a relationship with him on Facebook.

headline: b'How Facebook Is Changing to Deal With Scrutiny of Its Power'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Senator Elizabeth Warren has called for the breakup of big tech companies like Facebook. Regulators have opened investigations into Facebook’s power in social networking. Even one of Facebook’s own founders has laid out a case for why the company needs to be split up.

headline: b'Facebook Bans Ads From The Epoch Times'
lead_paragraph: Facebook has banned advertising from The Epoch Times, the Falun Gong-related publication and conservative news outlet, as the social network struggles to implement a consistent political advertising policy.

headline: b'Many Are Abandoning Facebook. These People Have the Opposite Problem.'
lead_paragraph: For a decade, Christopher Reeves, an Uber driver in Seattle, used Facebook for everything: talking with friends, communicating with fellow drivers, meeting singles. But one day in June, as he was uploading photos from a comic book convention and a family trip to Disneyland, he found himself abruptly logged out.

headline: b'Facebook Tightens Rules on Verifying Political Advertisers'
lead_paragraph: Facebook said Wednesday that it was strengthening how it verified which groups and people place political advertising on its site, as the social network braces for the 2020 presidential election in the United States and works to reduce the spread of online disinformation.

headline: b'Facebook Suspends Netanyahu Campaign Bot for Hate Speech'
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Facebook suspended a chatbot operated by the official account of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Thursday for violating hate speech rules after it sent a message saying that Israel’s Arab politicians “want to destroy us all.”

headline: b'Facebook Expands Definition of Terrorist Organizations to Limit Extremism'
lead_paragraph: Facebook unveiled a series of changes on Tuesday to limit hate speech and extremism on its site, as scrutiny is rising on how the social network may be radicalizing people.

headline: b'Facebook Tests Hiding \xe2\x80\x98Likes\xe2\x80\x99 on Social Media Posts'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, people who use Facebook, Instagram and Twitter have chased Likes as a status symbol. More Likes on a social media post meant it was popular, engaging and worthwhile.

headline: b'PayPal Pulls Out of Libra, Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Cryptocurrency Project'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — PayPal said on Friday that it had pulled out of the coalition of companies involved in a Facebook-backed cryptocurrency initiative, in the latest headache for the social network’s effort.

headline: b'Barr Pushes Facebook for Access to WhatsApp Messages'
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has renewed its fight for access to encrypted communications, arguing that it is a vital crime-fighting tool even as technology companies and advocates have countered that it will threaten individual privacy.

headline: b'Warren Dares Facebook With Intentionally False Political Ad'
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Elizabeth Warren is playing a game of dare with Facebook.

headline: b'Could Facebook Actually Nuke Elizabeth Warren\xe2\x80\x99s Campaign?'
lead_paragraph: This week, Facebook is embroiled in a different kind of election interference scandal.

headline: b'Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Libra Cryptocurrency Faces Exodus of Partners'
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s troubled cryptocurrency initiative, Libra, suffered new blows on Friday as the departures of key partners became an exodus.

headline: b'Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Hands-Off Approach to Political Speech Gets Impeachment Test'
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The 30-second video ad released by the Trump campaign last week is grainy, and the narrator’s voice is foreboding. Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., it says, offered Ukraine $1 billion in aid if the country pushed out the man investigating a company tied to Mr. Biden’s son.

headline: b'Biden Escalates Attack on Facebook Over False Political Ads'
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A 30-second video ad that ran on Facebook this week falsely accused former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. of blackmailing Ukrainian officials to stop an investigation of his son.

headline: b'Facebook Finally Has a Good Idea'
lead_paragraph: I would like to formally apply to be judge and jury over Mark Zuckerberg.

headline: b'Defiant Zuckerberg Says Facebook Won\xe2\x80\x99t Police Political Speech'
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Elizabeth Warren recently accused Facebook of being a “disinformation-for-profit machine.” Marc Benioff, chief executive of the online software maker Salesforce, said the social network “needs to be held accountable for propaganda on its platform.” And regulators around the world are examining whether to break the company up or clip its power.

headline: b'Facebook Calls Truce With Publishers as It Unveils Facebook News'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook and the publishing industry have long been frenemies: Occasionally they teamed up, but mostly they competed.

headline: b'Facebook Limetown - Trailer'
b'Zuckerberg to Admit That Facebook Has Trust Issues'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg hopes that one day, in the not too distant future, billions of people will use a cryptocurrency created by Facebook to send money to friends and family around the world.

headline: b'Mark Zuckerberg: Facebook Can Help the News Business'
lead_paragraph: When reporters at The Minnesota Star Tribune discovered that infant deaths had significantly increased in the state’s child care facilities, they published a series of articles that ended up driving changes in the law. They won a Pulitzer Prize in 2013 — and within months the infant mortality rate had dropped. As someone married to a pediatrician and committed to investing in solving health challenges, I found this to be a powerful example of how journalism can help us make progress on our biggest issues.

headline: b'Facebook Fiddles \xe2\x80\xa6'
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: b'Should Facebook Fact-Check Political Speech?'
lead_paragraph: In a speech at Georgetown University on Oct. 17, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, defended a sweeping policy the company unveiled last month around political speech on the site.

headline: b'Dissent Erupts at Facebook Over Hands-Off Stance on Political Ads'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The letter was aimed at Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, and his top lieutenants. It decried the social network’s recent decision to let politicians post any claims they wanted — even false ones — in ads on the site. It asked Facebook’s leaders to rethink the stance.

headline: b'Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s Earnings and Revenue Jump, Topping Forecasts'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook has been targeted by lawmakers over its treatment of political ads and has been misused by Russians to spread disinformation. But on Wednesday, the social network showed those challenges had little effect on its business.

headline: b'California Sues Facebook for Documents in Privacy Investigation'
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — California’s attorney general on Wednesday said he was investigating Facebook’s privacy practices and accused the company of failing to cooperate with his inquiry, in the social network’s latest fight over how it treats user information.

headline: b'Facebook Takes Down Breitbart Posts That Claimed to Name Whistle-Blower'
lead_paragraph: Facebook has taken down articles posted by the far-right site Breitbart that purported to identify the whistle-blower who triggered the impeachment inquiry of President Trump, just two weeks after including the site in the lineup of publishers whose work would be featured in a new news product.

headline: b'Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s New Role as News Publisher Brings New Scrutiny'
lead_paragraph: A little more than two weeks after Facebook announced a news initiative, the social network was on the defensive, responding to a published report that a website co-founded by the company’s top news executive had displayed bias against Elizabeth Warren.

headline: b'Why Everyone Is Angry at Facebook Over Its Political Ads Policy'
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After Google announced restrictions on political advertising this week, campaign strategists in Washington quickly turned their attention to a different company: Facebook.
